required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.official_title: Software to Translate Behavioral Economics Insights to Improve Health (Phase 2b)

collaborator.agency: Rhode Island Primary Care Physicians Corporation

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to determine whether a behavioral economics solution impacts smoking cessation program engagement and quit rates.

detailed_description.textblock: The behavioral economics solution is a weekly regret contest in which participants can win or miss out on money based on their behavior.

primary_outcome.measure: Average Number of Completed Sessions Per Participant
primary_outcome.time_frame: Every 30 days for up to 6 months post-enrollment
primary_outcome.description: Engagement rates for the intervention will be higher relative to the control arm. Engagement is measured by the number of complete tobacco cessation sessions per participant.

primary_outcome.time_frame: Every 30 days for up to 6 months post-enrollment
primary_outcome.description: Quit levels for the intervention will be higher relative to the control arm. Quit level is defined as a participant who progresses to the stage in the tobacco cessation program where they quit smoking. The quit stages are levels 4 and 5 of the tobacco cessation program.

arm_group.description: Participants in this arm receive usual care from the Pro-Change smoking cessation program, and receive compensation for enrolling and completing a survey at the end of the study.

Participants in this arm receive usual care from the Pro-Change smoking cessation program, the chance to win money based on their behavior (behavioral economics incentives), and receive compensation for enrolling and completing a survey at the end of the study.

intervention.description: Behavioral economics-informed incentives to promote engagement and outcomes in a smoking cessation intervention.
Minimal financial incentives to promote engagement and outcomes in a smoking cessation intervention.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Be current tobacco users (specifically smokers)
- Be 18 years old or over
Exclusion Criteria:
- Pregnant women

patient_data.ipd_description: Individual participant data will not be made available to other researchers.

participant_flow.recruitment_details: Recruitment period: January to March, 2016. Recruitment methods: Physician and nurse referrals from Rhode Island Primary Care Physicians Corporation and Facebook advertisements. Intake method: Digital intake form hosted by Pro-Change.
participant_flow.pre_assignment_details: We identified and discontinued 34 participants whose accounts were were flagged as being suspicious. Duplicate accounts were erroneously created by a participant and thus were removed from the study. Suspicious accounts contained personal information identical to existing participants and after investigation, were concluded to be fraudulent.

group.title: Usual Care With Minimal Incentives
group.description: Participants in this arm receive usual care from the Pro-Change smoking cessation program, and receive compensation for enrolling and completing a survey at the end of the study. Minimal incentives: Minimal financial incentives to promote engagement, and outcomes in a smoking cessation intervention.

group.title: Usual Care With BE Incentives
group.description: Participants in this arm receive usual care from the Pro-Change smoking cessation program, the chance to win money based on their behavior (Behavioral economics incentives), and receive compensation for enrolling and completing a survey at the end of the study. Behavioral economics incentives: Behavioral economics-informed incentives to promote engagement and outcomes in a smoking cessation intervention.

certain_agreements.pi_employee: All Principal Investigators ARE employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: There is NOT an agreement between Principal Investigators and the Sponsor (or its agents) that restricts the PI's rights to discuss or publish trial results after the trial is completed.
